NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                Home       About Us       People       Undergraduate Program       Graduate program       Events       Employment             Stay Connected           Facebook             Affiliations         Center for French Civilization and Culture           La Maison Francaise           Institute of French Studies           NYU Paris                    Back to Home               Phillip Usher       Associate Professor of French         Office Address:   19 University Place, 6th floor  New York, NY 10003   Office Hours:   Mon., 4:30pm - 6:30pm   Email:     pu8@nyu.edu     Phone:   212-998-8707   Fax:   212-995-4187   Personal Homepage:     http://phillipjohnusher.weebly.com         Bio   My research focuses on all genres of sixteenth-century literature, from lyric poetry, epic, tragedy, and essayistic prose to works that would, according to more modern classifications, be considered para-literary, such as universal histories, treatises on geography, architecture, art history, or on such topics as mining or metals. At the heart of my work is an impulse to seek out both precise and hypothetical connections both between texts and between texts and non-textual artefacts, in an ongoing attempt to trace out how literature produces the spaces in which we live, our concrete and poetic habitats, as well as human ecologies and global imaginaries. My main interdisciplinary connections are thus with human/cultural/theoretical geography, art history, and (of late) environmental science. I have written on various topics, including the tension between religious and scientific cartographies, the proliferation of "epic building sites" that connect literature and other art forms, as well as on epic literature's "mapping" of local, national, and global spaces in the early-modern period. My two main projects at present are 1) a book on Montaigne as an author "in the world" and 2) a book about what I am calling the "Humanist Anthropocene." In this latter project, I am seeking out connections between early-modern humanism and our 21st-century reality of living on a globalized planet that humans are influencing at a geological scale. I am also a translator. I look forward to working with graduate students on all topics related historically or theoretically to my work.                                       Major Publications  Epic Arts in Renaissance France. (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014).  Illustrations inconscientes: écritures de la Renaissance. Mélanges offers à Tom Conley. Volume co-edited with Bernd Renner (Paris: Classiques Garnier, 2014).  Building the Louvre: Architectures of Politics and Art. Volume co-edited with Patrick bray. (Volume of L’Esprit créateur, Baltimore, Johns Hopkins University Press, 2014).  Virgilian Identities in Renaissance France . Volume co-edited with Isabelle Fernbach (London: Boydell and Brewer, June 2012).  Ronsard’s Franciad . A translation, with introduction and notes. (New York: AMS Press, 2010).  Errance et cohérence: Essai sur la littérature transfrontalière à la Renaissance (Paris: Classiques-Garnier, 2010).
